item.description:
Thanksgiving is a time to take a step back, reflect, and to give thanks for all the people in your life. Families gather together to celebrate a meal in the afternoon, but what better way to kick off the day than by volunteering together at a race that gives back to the community?

On Thanksgiving morning, Run Against Cancer Events is hosting the Turkey5 Road Race in Wellesley. With both 5K and 5Mile courses, the Turkey5 offers something for everyone.  Starting and finishing at Linden Square, runners will head through the beautiful Wellesley College campus and the marathon’s famous “Scream Tunnel” section before seeing the “1 mile to go!” sign.

Beneficiaries include the Greater Boston Food Bank, The Ellie Fund, and the Wellesley Cancer Prevention Project. We've seen great support already from the Wellesley community and the Boston area in general - now we just need some extra help on the volunteer end to establish the race as an annual tradition we'll all be proud of for years to come! We're looking for all sorts of help, and no previous road race experience is necessary - just a desire to give back & have fun!

Race day schedule:

6:00am - Volunteers check-in

6:30am – registration opens

7:30am – registration closes

8:00am – race begins (both 5K & 5M)

Possible volunteer duties include:

- Packet pick-up (on days leading up to the event and/or on race morning)

- Bag check

- Course support

- Water stops

- Bag check

- Finish line support

- Dressing up in costume & having a blast (lots of photo opportunities)! It is not BYOC - we'll provide the festive costumes!

- Pitching in wherever it looks necessary!

More info and to sign up -https://www.racemenu.com/turkey5volunteer

 

The Boston Volunteers
Big enough to Deliver, small enough to care
Learn more: www.BostonVolunteer.org

Learn more about your fellow Boston Volunteers:

 

P.S. Many Boston Volunteers are friending our friend popular Paulette.

Who is Paulette: http://www.facebook.com/paulette.revere.7

group.name: Boston Volunteers. Big enough 2 deliver, small enough 2 care
